title: Freestyle skiing: Korean moguls skiers banned for sexual harassment
text: March 15, 2018 / 3:39 AM / Updated 7 hours ago Freestyle skiing: Korean moguls skiers banned for sexual harassment Reuters Staff 1 Min Read SEOUL (Reuters) - Two male South Korean moguls skiers who competed at the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics have been banned for life after female team mates complained of being sexually harassed at an event in Japan, the Korea Ski Association (KSA) has said. Freestyle Skiing – Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympics – Moguls Training – Phoenix Snow Park – Pyeongchang, South Korea – February 7, 2018 - Choi Jae-woo of South Korea trains. REUTERS/Mike Blake A KSA official said on Thursday that Choi Jae-woo and Kim Ji-hyun had been banned on March 12 after they “assaulted and sexually harassed fellow female athletes during a World Cup event in Japan”. The complainants had asked police to investigate the incident, the official added. Choi advanced to the men’s moguls final in Pyeongchang last month but did not finish his second run. Kim was eliminated in qualifying. Reporting by Choi Haejin, Writing by Peter Rutherford; Editing by John O'Brien
